thread.title: GWS Giants premiership hopes, flag favourites, squad age, squad depth | The Courier-Mail
thread.title_full: GWS Giants premiership hopes, flag favourites, squad age, squad depth | The Courier-Mail

title: GWS Giants premiership hopes, flag favourites, squad age, squad depth | The Courier-Mail
text:
The one hole that could hinder Greater Western Sydney’s 2017 premiership hopes Riley Beveridge, FOX SPORTS February 22, 2017 1:19pm 
ON PAPER at least, Greater Western Sydney makes for a daunting flag favourite. 
Blessed with a young and talented best 22 that is sure to improve on its first finals appearance last year, the Giants began their pre-season campaign in emphatic style over the weekend. 
Unsurprisingly, given the club’s rapid rise since its inception, some bold predictions about its potential dominance in 2017 has followed — some more audacious than others. 
“Don’t be surprised if at some stage later this year, they score almost 40 goals in a game,” Essendon great Tim Watson said on SEN on Wednesday. 
“At some stage, they will get on a roll against a side — mid-season and they’re down and depleted — and they’ve got the capacity to do that, more than any side.” 
Yet is there a depth-related issue waiting in the wings for Leon Cameron’s team? 
The foundations for the Western Bulldogs’ 2016 premiership victory were built upon a strong squad that was able to cover for a series of depleting injury issues. 
Having parted with nine depth players via trades last season — and two more through retirements and delistings — the Giants might not necessarily have that quality in reserve this year. 
A further 17 players left the club in the two years prior as list bosses dealt with checks and balances surrounding the club’s early draft concessions. 
Such has been the club’s willingness to part with players on the fringes of its best team, the Giants now have only Jeremy Finlayson (taken with Pick 85) to show from their 2014 draft haul. 
As a result, players like Jack Steele, Caleb Marchbank and Will Hoskin-Elliott will likely become best 22 prospects at rival sides, rather than supplementing a Giants premiership charge. 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > media_camera Tim Taranto was the first player picked by the Giants during last year’s draft. 
In their place, the Giants could be forced to lean on several youngsters plucked from the draft or the club’s academy — should injury strike at any stage throughout the year. 
It’s by no means a death sentence for the team’s flag chances — just look at how some of those kids played in last weekend’s clash with West Coast. 
Tim Taranto, claimed with Pick 2 in last year’s national draft, racked up 21 disposals to go with six clearances and seven inside 50s in an impressive display on his unofficial debut. 
Will Setterfield and Harry Perryman were also sound across the field, while 2015 academy recruit Matthew Kennedy (22 disposals and five inside 50s) was one of the team’s best. 
Lachie Tiziani, taken with Pick 54 last year, also showed promising glimpses of his talent. 
However, such a reliance on youngsters for a side competing for a flag is less than ideal. 
To put it into perspective, the Bulldogs rotated 39 players through its best team throughout its 2016 campaign — four more than the bulging Giants used. 
Considering that squad has been shaved further this year, it could be a headache for Cameron. 
“The fact remains — and we saw this last year — you only have to beat the Giants on one day,” Watson added on Wednesday. 
“You don’t have to beat them 22 times over the course of the year. You just have to do what the Bulldogs did last year — get your match-ups right, get your planning right, nullify their strengths, play through your strengths — and you’re capable of winning. 
“I don’t subscribe to this theory that everyone is playing for positions outside of the flag next year.” 
Given the Giants have the third-most experienced list in terms of games played (average of 76) and the second-oldest squad (average of 24y 219d), the disparity in age profile between the best 22 and those waiting in the wings is large. 
But will it prove a hindrance for the flag favourites? Or will those youngsters just add to the increasing likelihood of a Giants dynasty?
